I have a friend who‚Äôs related to some human rights activities who were recently arrested. The following is information which I - for what it‚Äôs worth - consider reliable:

  • Their phones and PCs were penetrated either via technical or human engineering means.
  • They all had Signal installed on their phones (mostly Android).
  • The troubling part is that the interrogators showed them Signal messages from a while ago - messages that were supposed to be deleted via the automatic ‚Äúdisappearing messages‚Äù mechanism.

My question - is that technically possible? If so - can you guess how?

Random thoughts: Even if the interrogators managed to get access to the message database, as well as to to encryption key from the Android Keystore (or equivalent on other device types) - old messages should have been completely removed from both database and physical storage - shouldn‚Äôt they?

Any assistance or thoughts would be greatly appreciated.

there‚Äôs several scenarios i can see here.

  1. they set disappearing messages only after sending a few messages and didn‚Äôt realise the feature doesn‚Äôt work retroactively (because it doesn‚Äôt).
    the way to protect against that attack vector would be to be more careful about setting disappearing messages in advance and checking what was sent.
  2. one of the chat members is a mole who gave the messages to the police. no way to protect against that except for making sure you don‚Äôt have a mole in your group - disappearing messages are ineffective in that scenario.
  3. one or more devices were compromised in advance. this is basically identical to the mole scenario, and there‚Äôs no good way to protect against it other than not getting hacked.

as @Avitus correctly said, we can‚Äôt really determine between these scenarios without more info.

JudQQ:

Their phones and PCs were penetrated either via technical or human engineering means.

If they have linked Signal devices on PC then those devices have to receive messages before the linked device are able to determine that it is an expired disappearing message and delete it. The server doesn‚Äôt know if a message is disappearing or not so those messages will still be there until it is received by linked device. Then Signal Desktop can be modified (easy to do because JavaScript) to not delete disappearing messages.

Also if the devices have screen logger virus or capture.

DonDino:

Yes but it‚Äôs legit to ask whether deleted or disappeared messages are irrecoverable as opposed to just not being visible anymore in the conversation. If it‚Äôs the latter, then it‚Äôs pretty bad for user expectations since it‚Äôs not disclosed.

Of course, it‚Äôs absolutely legit.

Then you come into a conversation of forensically recovering deleted bits from the device SSD, which may well be possible and Signal does not protect against - and you have to go into this, as if you just say ‚Äúyes, Signal deletes the messages from the database‚Äù, someone who has no knowledge of forensics would think there is no trace left.

DonDino:

which may well be possible and Signal does not protect against

It‚Äôs doesn‚Äôt have to be this way, endpoint security is important just like E2EE. On mobile, there are many ways to encrypt data in a way that discarding encryption keys makes data completely unrecoverable. On desktop the situation is more lackluster and fragmented but it‚Äôs possible considering they already have database encryption going on with SQLCipher.

JudQQ:

So it, for example, a new device is registered under my user will it receive all the messages since a certain point in time, and the delete the ones that are marked for deletion?

Yes, it will pretty much do exactly that.

A device sends a message to the server. This message is encrypted and has a timestamp of when it was sent.

The server then recieves this message and all devices that are supposed to receive it can grab it from there, while the server keeps it long enough to do this, even if some people currently aren‚Äôt online.

Usually, a device that is already registered to your account and temporarily is not connected to the servers will recieve all missed messages as soon as it reconnects. The same goes for other recipients‚Äô primary and linked devices.

However, the server only keeps the messages for a specified amount of time (I believe maybe 45 days, but please correct me if I‚Äôm wrong). This time is counted from the moment the message arrives to the server. After this time has run out, the message is deleted from the server, regardless of whether it has been recieved by everyone or not.

After a recipient device pulls a message from the server, it decrypts it with is internal key and on the inside there might be a disappearing timer. If this timer has already run out, the message is then deleted from the device.

It is absolutely possible to adapt the signal application on the recipient device to not do this, keep all messages and ignore the timer. It is however not possible to manipulate a device to pull messages older than 45 days (or whatever the server limit might be) because they are simply no longer on the server.

The timer feature can not protect against a compromised device or application.

When you do a device transfer, the older messages are transferred directly from one device to the other, because they no longer exist on the server. In this case any messages that has already been deleted from the first device (whether by tinder or manually), can not reappear on the new device, because they are no longer available anywhere. Messages with active timers of less than some limit (I think 24 hours) are also not transferred, but this can again be circumvented with adapted applications on the devices.

posts.cooked:
JudQQ:

If the server is unaware of the expiration date, and it just sends everything the user should have received over the last ~45 days, why wouldn‚Äôt attack vector #2 work?

If you could explain how keys are used to prevent that (or how they are used more generally), that would be great (and thanks again and in advance).

Senders only send messages to devices that exist on the account at the time the message was sent. Each device has it‚Äôs own message encryption keys. You cannot decrypt a message sent to device #1 with device #2‚Äôs keys under any circumstance. Adding a device after messages were already sent does not give the new device a copy of those messages.

Each device on the account has a separate message queue. The message queue is not shared between devices. Messages waiting for device #2 might not also be waiting for device #1 if device #1 was able to retrieve messages from the server.

NeedsChloesure:

Each device has it‚Äôs own message encryption keys. You cannot decrypt a message sent to device #1 with device #2‚Äôs keys under any circumstance.

Yes, exactly. My previous statement applies to devices that were already connected at the time the message was sent. These devices would be able to decrypt the message (and then ignore the timer if they were modified in that way). The message would only be sent to the server encrypted for all devices that are currently linked, new ones couldn‚Äôt later decrypt them, even if they acquired it, because it can‚Äôt be decrypted with their key.

Also note that a modification to ignore timers doesn‚Äôt have to be malicious. Maybe someone wants to preserve a group chat, that has a disappearing timer set, for personal reasons, that doesn‚Äôt mean they‚Äôre going to use it against the senders.

JudQQ:

explain how keys are used to prevent that

Generally, for each device (whether it is a primary or a linked device) two keys are issued.

One is meant for encryption. It can be used by anyone to encrypt messages for only that device to decrypt. This is a public key, because it could be told to anyone without an issue. This key can not decrypt messages that have been encrypted by itself.

The other key is meant to decrypt messages that were encrypted by the first one. It is a private key, because it unlocks everything meant for that device and should therefore be kept safe.

When a contact (or link) is established, the devices exchange public keys. One can then encrypt messages such that only the other can decrypt them.

This means that messages on the server are only of use to a device if they were encrypted with its public key (i.e. meant for it), but it also means that a device that has the key can decrypt these messages as long as they are there.
